title: After the AP Computer Science Data Science Capstone
text: This resource is intended for high school computer science teachers seeking to extend student learning beyond AP Computer Science courses. It provides a teacher-facing guide for the After the AP Capstone.The materials for the capstone are designed for students who have completed AP Computer Science Principles or AP Computer Science A, or who have comparable experience with text-based programming.

title: Introduction
text:
Purpose
This resource is a teacher guide for a data investigation project designed to extend student learning beyond AP Computer Science courses. The guide supports high school computer science teachers in planning and facilitating a data science project that builds on students’ prior programming experience and does not assume prior coursework in statistics or data science.
It explains the structure of the project, the dataset used, and the types of analyses students are expected to pursue. The project is intended for students who have completed AP Computer Science Principles or AP Computer Science A, or who have comparable experience with text-based programming.

title: 4  Summary
text:
In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.

1 + 1

title: After the AP Computer Science Data Science Capstone
section: After the AP Computer Science Capstone
text:
After the AP Computer Science Capstone
This resource supports high school computer science teachers in extending student learning beyond AP Computer Science A. It provides a set of Jupyter notebooks that emphasize data investigation and analysis while reinforcing core programming practices aligned with the CSTA 3.0 Standards.
The materials are intended for students who have completed AP CS A or who have comparable experience with text-based programming.

title: After the AP Computer Science Data Science Capstone
text:
Purpose
This resource extends typical AP Computer Science A experiences by emphasizing the use of programming for data investigation and analysis. Students apply familiar programming constructs to explore real-world data, identify patterns, and communicate findings, without introducing new programming paradigms.

title: After the AP Computer Science Data Science Capstone
text:
Dataset: General Social Survey (GSS)
All notebooks use data from the General Social Survey (GSS), a nationally representative survey of U.S. adults conducted since 1972 and funded by the National Science Foundation.
The GSS includes demographic, behavioral, and attitudinal variables covering topics such as public opinion, social mobility, well-being, and civil liberties. Its breadth and longitudinal structure make it well suited for student data investigations that are both meaningful and interpretable.

title: After the AP Computer Science Data Science Capstone
text:
Standards Alignment
The notebooks align with CSTA 3.0, with emphasis on:

Programming — applying control structures, data structures, and functions in data contexts

Data & Analysis — transforming, analyzing, and interpreting data to answer questions

The focus is on using existing programming knowledge in new contexts.

title: After the AP Computer Science Data Science Capstone
text:
How to Use This Resource
These materials may be used as:

A post-AP CS A unit

An extension alongside or after a capstone experience

A bridge to data-focused projects or courses

Each notebook is modular, adaptable, and does not assume prior coursework in statistics or data science.

title: Introduction
text:
Data Science Tools Used



This project uses Python with the pandas library for data manipulation (McKinney 2010) and the matplotlib library for data visualization (Hunter 2007).

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.3 Dataset: General Social Survey (GSS)
All notebooks use data from the General Social Survey (GSS), a nationally representative survey of U.S. adults conducted since 1972 and funded by the National Science Foundation.
The GSS includes demographic, behavioral, and attitudinal variables covering topics such as public opinion, social mobility, well-being, and civil liberties. Its breadth and longitudinal structure make it well suited for student data investigations that are both meaningful and interpretable.

title: Introduction
text:
Standards Alignment
The project aligns with both the Programming and Data & Analysis topics from the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) Standards and the Data Science Learning Progressions.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.5 How to Use This Resource

Each notebook is modular, adaptable, and does not assume prior coursework in statistics or data science. # Introduction

title: After the AP Computer Science Data Science Capstone
text:
This resource is intended for high school computer science teachers seeking to extend student learning beyond AP Computer Science courses. It provides a teacher-facing guide for a data investigation project.
The materials are designed for students who have completed AP Computer Science Principles or AP Computer Science A, or who have comparable experience with text-based programming.

title: After the AP Computer Science Data Science Capstone
text:
Test
This resource is intended for high school computer science teachers seeking to extend student learning beyond AP Computer Science courses. It provides a teacher-facing guide for a data investigation project.
The materials are designed for students who have completed AP Computer Science Principles or AP Computer Science A, or who have comparable experience with text-based programming.

title: Introduction
text:
Dataset
The project uses data from the General Social Survey (GSS). The GSS is primarily funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) and conducted by the National Opinion Research Center (NORC), the non-partisan and objective research organization at the University of Chicago. The GSS collects data on a variety of topics in contemporary American society to monitor and explain trends in opinions, attitudes, and behaviors.
The GSS contains a standard core of demographic, behavioral, and attitudinal questions, plus topics of special interest. Among the topics covered are education, civil liberties, national spending priorities, psychological well-being, and social mobility. It allows researchers to examine the structure and functioning of society in general, as well as the role played by relevant subgroups.

title: Dataset
text:
General Social Survey
The project uses data from the General Social Survey (GSS). The GSS is primarily funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) and conducted by the National Opinion Research Center (NORC), the non-partisan and objective research organization at the University of Chicago. The GSS collects data on a variety of topics in contemporary American society to monitor and explain trends in opinions, attitudes, and behaviors.
The GSS contains a standard core of demographic, behavioral, and attitudinal questions, plus topics of special interest. Among the topics covered are education, civil liberties, national spending priorities, psychological well-being, and social mobility. It allows researchers to examine the structure and functioning of society in general, as well as the role played by relevant subgroups.

title: 2  Introduction
text:
2.2 Dataset
The project uses data from the General Social Survey (GSS). The GSS is primarily funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) and conducted by the National Opinion Research Center (NORC), the non-partisan and objective research organization at the University of Chicago. The GSS collects data on a variety of topics in contemporary American society to monitor and explain trends in opinions, attitudes, and behaviors.
The GSS contains a standard core of demographic, behavioral, and attitudinal questions, plus topics of special interest. Among the topics covered are education, civil liberties, national spending priorities, psychological well-being, and social mobility. It allows researchers to examine the structure and functioning of society in general, as well as the role played by relevant subgroups.

title: 2  Introduction
text:
2.3 Standards Alignment
The project aligns with both the Programming and Data & Analysis topics from the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) Standards and the Data Science Learning Progressions.

title: 2  Dataset
text:
2.2 General Social Survey
Currently, the GSS is designed by a set of Primary Investigators (PIs), with input from the GSS Board, comprised of notable researchers within the scientific community.
However, due to the global COVID19 pandemic, the 2021 GSS Cross-section implemented significant methodological adaptations for the safety of respondents and interviewers, most notably shifting to an address-based sampling with push to web and a web self-administered questionnaire. The 2022 GSS Cross-section bridges the traditional face-to-face data collection of the GSS from 1972-2018 with the web-based collection of 2021, keeping many of the questionnaire changes brought about by the new mode, while reverting to a mixed mode data collection that include face to face, web and telephone. The 2022 GSS was designed to facilitate a comparison to the 2018 GSS; that is, the 2022 study aimed to resemble the 2018 GSS. Additionally, the 2022 GSS retained several methodological experiments conducted in the 2021 GSS that are specific to the web mode. The 2022 GSS is the first round of a multi-round transition to a mixed-mode survey, fielded both face-to-face and via web self-administered questionnaire.

title: 2  Dataset
text:
2.2 Background & Methodology
The GSS is a nationally representative series of cross-sectional interviews conducted in the United States since 1972. By adapting questions from earlier surveys, the GSS enables comparisons across decades. Originally proposed by James A. Davis, the survey has been administered by NORC at the University of Chicago and funded by the NSF since its inception. The GSS is currently designed by a set of Primary Investigators, with guidance from a Board of researchers.
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the 2021 GSS implemented methodological changes, including a shift to address-based sampling with a push-to-web, self-administered questionnaire. The 2022 GSS was designed as a bridge between the traditional face-to-face data collection used from 1972–2018 and the web-based approach introduced in 2021. It retained many questionnaire changes from the web mode while returning to a mixed-mode design that included face-to-face, web, and telephone data collection. The 2022 GSS was structured to facilitate comparison with the 2018 GSS and represents the first stage of a broader transition to a mixed-mode survey.

title: Dataset
text:
About the General Social Survey
The GSS is a nationally representative series of cross-sectional interviews conducted in the United States since 1972. By adapting questions from earlier surveys, the GSS enables comparisons across decades. Originally proposed by James A. Davis, the survey has been administered by NORC at the University of Chicago and funded by the NSF since its inception. The GSS is currently designed by a set of Primary Investigators, with guidance from a Board of researchers.
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the 2021 GSS implemented methodological changes, including a shift to address-based sampling with a push-to-web, self-administered questionnaire. The 2022 GSS was designed as a bridge between the traditional face-to-face data collection used from 1972–2018 and the web-based approach introduced in 2021. It retained many questionnaire changes from the web mode while returning to a mixed-mode design that included face-to-face, web, and telephone data collection. The 2022 GSS was structured to facilitate comparison with the 2018 GSS and represents the first stage of a broader transition to a mixed-mode survey.

Belief that working hard is needed to get ahead

Belief that knowing the right people is needed to get ahead


opwlth
Belief that coming from a wealthy family is needed to get ahead


opeduc
Belief that a good education is needed to get ahead

title: Variables
text:
Missing & Non-Substantive Codes
This section describes codes used to represent missing, inapplicable, or non-substantive responses in the GSS. Missing and non-substantive codes appear in survey data when a question does not apply to a respondent, was skipped, or could not be answered. These values are not errors.
Some missing values occur because a question was never asked (for example, it was not included in a particular survey year), while others reflect meaningful responses such as “don’t know” or “not applicable.”
When analyzing the data, these codes should be handled intentionally. In most cases, they should be excluded from summaries and visualizations, rather than treated as valid responses.








Code
Meaning
Notes & When It Appears




NaN
Missing value (numeric)
Pandas missing value; appears in numeric columns


.i:  Inapplicable
Inapplicable
Question does not apply due to skip patterns or survey design


.n:  No answer
No answer
Question was asked, but no valid response recorded


.d:  Do not Know/Cannot Choose
Don’t know / cannot choose
Respondent could not or would not provide a substantive answer


.s:  Skipped on Web
Skipped on web
Respondent skipped the question in web-based surveys


.y:  Not available in this year
Not asked in this year
Variable not included in that survey year









Working with Missing Values



Missing and non-substantive codes are not errors. They indicate when a question did not apply, was skipped, or could not be answered. These values should usually be excluded from summaries and visualizations.

title: Resources
text:
Video Resources
The General Social Survey (GSS) YouTube channel has an educational video series designed to support instructors, students, and researchers using GSS data.

title: Resources
text:
Introduction to the GSS
Provides a brief overview of the GSS, including its history, key stakeholders, and selected academic contributions. The video positions the GSS as a widely used data resource for undergraduate instruction and research.


GSS Project Process & Life Cycle
Explains the full lifecycle of the GSS survey, including proposal review, testing, programming, pilot studies, data collection, cleaning, dissemination, and user support.


The GSS Structure & Basics
Describes the structure of the GSS, including core content, experiments, cross-sectional and panel studies, ISSP modules, and the balloting process. The video also covers basic skills for navigating, downloading, and interpreting GSS data.


Sampling in the GSS
Explains how representative samples are drawn for the GSS and introduces key sampling concepts used in the survey.


Total Survey Error in the GSS
Discusses sources of error in survey data, including nonresponse error, coverage error, sampling error, and measurement error.


GSS Wording Experiments
Provides examples of how question wording affects responses, highlighting GSS contributions to understanding measurement effects (e.g., national spending priority items).


The GSS Data Explorer
Offers a tutorial on using the GSS Data Explorer, including online analytics, visualizations, and features introduced in Data Explorer 2.0.


GSS for Educators
Targeted to instructors, this video shares ideas for incorporating GSS data into lesson plans and classroom activities.


GSS for STEM
Focuses on working with data beyond survey responses, including paradata and linked datasets such as the death index.


Taking a Deep Dive into GSS Content
Provides an overview of major variable groups and content areas, highlighting resources and recent trends relevant to researchers and educators.

title: Dataset
text:
The Project Dataset
The dataset used for this project is a subset of the full GSS dataset, downloaded on December 31, 2025. The original dataset contained 46 variables and 75,699 observations.

Data Preparation & Cleaning
The dataset used in this project is based on the original GSS data but includes pre-processing steps to support classroom use and analysis.
The following changes were made prior to student use:

A subset of variables and observations relevant to the project was selected.
Non-substantive response codes (e.g., .i:  Inapplicable, .n:  No answer) were kept in their original form; some were removed or recoded during cleaning.
The variable age_group was created.
Variables originally labeled cohort and year were renamed to birth_year and survey_year.
The variable wwwhr was recoded from categorical response values to numeric.
The dataset was filtered to include respondents age 51 and under.

These steps were taken to reduce complexity while preserving the structure and integrity of the original survey data.
Teachers and students should be aware that the dataset is not a raw extract from the GSS, but a prepared version intended for instructional use.


Tidy and Tame Data Considerations
The project dataset has been prepared to follow principles of tidy data (Wickham 2014) and tame data (Kim, Ismay, and Chunn 2018) to support exploratory analysis.
In this dataset:

Each row represents a single institution.
Each column represents a single variable.
Each cell contains a single, well-defined value.

Variables were also selected and organized to make the dataset tame, meaning, manageable, interpretable, and appropriate for classroom analysis. This includes limiting the number of variables, using consistent naming conventions, and providing variables that are meaningful for comparative analysis across institutions.
These design choices reduce unnecessary data wrangling and allow students to focus on asking questions, exploring patterns, and interpreting results, while still working with authentic, real-world data.




Kim, Albert Y., Chester Ismay, and Jennifer Chunn. 2018. “The Fivethirtyeight r Package: ’Tame Data’ Principles for Introductory Statistics and Data Science Courses.” Technology Innovations in Statistics Education 11 (1). https://escholarship.org/uc/item/0rx1231m.


Wickham, Hadley. 2014. “Tidy Data.” Journal of Statistical Software 59. https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v059.i10.

title: 4  Notebooks
text:
4.1 Jupyter Notebooks
This project is implemented using Jupyter notebooks, which serve as the primary workspace for data analysis. Jupyter notebooks combine code, text, and visual output in a single environment.
A reference guide summarizing the Python libraries, functions, and methods used across the notebooks is provided later in this guide.

title: 4  Notebooks
text:
4.2 Notebook Descriptions

4.2.1 Notebook 1: Introduction to Jupyter Notebooks (Optional)
Introduces the Jupyter notebook environment and basic workflow, including running cells, editing code, and formatting text.


4.2.2 Notebook 2: Basic Python and Data Structures
Introduces Python data structures for students transitioning from Java, with a focus on lists, dictionaries, and iteration as tools for working with data.


4.2.3 Notebook 3: Pandas and Basic Data Exploration
Introduces Pandas for loading datasets, inspecting variables, and computing basic summary statistics.


4.2.4 Notebook 4: Visualizing Distributions
Introduces Matplotlib for creating visualizations to explore and interpret the distribution of numerical variables.


4.2.5 Notebook 5: Visualizing Trends
Examines patterns and trends over time using computational tools and visual evidence.


4.2.6 Notebook 6: Exploring Relationships and Trends
Emphasizes student choice by allowing students to explore questions of interest, investigate relationships between variables, and support claims with data.

title: 6  Code Reference
text:
6.1 Python Libraries Used
Python libraries are collections of prewritten code that support common tasks. This project uses pandas for data analysis and matplotlib for data visualization.

title: 6  Code Reference
text:
6.1.1 Pandas
pandas is a Python library used for working with structured, tabular data. It provides tools for loading datasets, selecting and transforming variables, computing summary statistics, and preparing data for analysis.


6.1.2 Matplotlib
matplotlib is a Python library used for creating visual representations of data. In this project, it is used to generate charts and graphs to explore distributions, compare groups, and examine trends.

dictionaries

Filtering rows

title: Helpful Notebook Tips
text:
Introduction to Jupyter Notebook
A Jupyter Notebook is a web-based interactive computing environment that supports programming in Python, R, and other languages (Stokes and Harding 2025). In this project, you will use Jupyter Notebooks to write code, explore data, and document your analysis.

title: 4  Helpful Notebook Tips
text:
Avoid Multiple Tabs



Avoid opening multiple notebooks in separate tabs, as this can lead to memory overload, forcing you to restart your session.

title: Helpful Notebook Tips
text:
Code & Text Cells
A Jupyter Notebook has three types of cells. For this project, you will use only two:

Code cells for writing and running Python code
Markdown or text cells for entering written responses.


Running Cells in a Jupyter Notebook
In a Jupyter Notebook, you run cells one at a time to see code output or display formatted text. To run a cell, click inside the cell and then click the Run button in the toolbar at the top of the notebook.



Run button in the Jupyter toolbar


You can also use keyboard shortcuts:

PCs and Chromebooks: Hold Ctrl and press Enter
Macs: Hold Command (⌘) and press Enter



Adding Cells
Use the + button in the top toolbar to add a new cell.



+ button in the Jupyter toolbar


Then set the cell type as needed:



Code or Markdown button in the Jupyter toolbar



Choose Code for code
Choose Markdown for text



Running All Cells from Top Down
The Save button saves your code and text, but it does not save data stored in memory. Whenever you reopen a notebook, you should re-run all code cells from the top.
To do this, go to Kernel → Restart & Run All.






Restart & Run All



This option restarts the notebook and runs every cell in order from top to bottom. If a code cell encounters an error, execution will stop and later cells will not run.





Restart & Run All button in the Jupyter toolbar






Stokes, David J., and Mahmoud Harding. 2025. “A Project-Based Approach to Introductory R and Python for Data Science.” https://djstokes02.github.io/IntroRPython4DS/.

title: Useful Python Commands
text: Notebook 1: Basic Python & Data Structures

title: 5  Introduction
text:
Data Science Tools Used



This project uses Python with the pandas library for data manipulation (McKinney 2010) and the matplotlib library for data visualization (Hunter 2007).

title: 5  Introduction
text:
5.2 Dataset
The project uses data from the General Social Survey (GSS). The GSS is primarily funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) and conducted by the National Opinion Research Center (NORC), the non-partisan and objective research organization at the University of Chicago. The GSS collects data on a variety of topics in contemporary American society to monitor and explain trends in opinions, attitudes, and behaviors.
The GSS contains a standard core of demographic, behavioral, and attitudinal questions, plus topics of special interest. Among the topics covered are education, civil liberties, national spending priorities, psychological well-being, and social mobility. It allows researchers to examine the structure and functioning of society in general, as well as the role played by relevant subgroups.

title: 5  Introduction
text:
5.3 Standards Alignment
The project aligns with both the Programming and Data & Analysis topics from the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) Standards and the Data Science Learning Progressions.




Hunter, John D. 2007. “Matplotlib: A 2D Graphics Environment.” Computing in Science & Engineering 9 (3): 90–95. https://matplotlib.org/.


McKinney, Wes. 2010. “Data Structures for Statistical Computing in Python.” Proceedings of the 9th Python in Science Conference, 56–61. https://doi.org/10.25080/Majora-92bf1922-00a.

Notebook 6: Exploring Relationships & Trends in Survey Data

Overview of the Steps

Choose two variables to compare (groups or time + a survey question response).
Decide whether you are examining a relationship or a trend.
Write a comparison question.
Prepare the data for analysis.
Create summaries and visualizations.
Describe what the data shows.



3.0 – Data Exploration & Visualization

Insert code cells to create summaries and visualizations.
After each code cell, add a short explanation of what the output shows and how it helps answer the question.

title: Helpful Notebook Tips
text:
Overview of a Jupyter Notebook
Jupyter notebooks allow users to create and share documents that combine code, equations, visualizations, and formatted text (Stokes and Harding 2025). They are commonly used for data science because users can write and run code step by step, document their thinking, and view results directly alongside the code that produced them.






Avoid Multiple Tabs



Avoid opening multiple notebooks in separate tabs, as this can lead to memory overload, forcing you to restart your session.

title: Useful Python Commands
text:
Variables and Assignment
Python variables are created by assignment. A valid Python variable name must start with a letter or an underscore, use only letters, numbers, and underscores, and can’t be a reserved Python keyword.
Example

_five = 5
pi = 3.14159
course_name = "Data Science"

print(_five)
print(pi)
print(course_name)

5
3.14159
Data Science




Numeric Operations
Python supports standard arithmetic operations.
Example

print(_five + pi)
print(_five * pi)
print(_five / 2)
print(_five ** 2)

8.14159
15.70795
2.5
25




Lists
Lists store ordered collections of values. They can contain elements of different data types such as numbers, strings, and booleans.
Example

numbers = [1, 2, "3", 4, 5]
mixed_list = [True, 2.0, 3, "four", 5.]

print(numbers)
print(mixed_list)

[1, 2, '3', 4, 5]
[True, 2.0, 3, 'four', 5.0]




2.0 – Python for This Project: Data Structures

Lists
(Dictionaries are introduced in this same section, alongside lists.)



4.0 – For Loops in Python
